model_output:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) refers to the simulation of human intelligence processes by machines, as discussed in [1]. The authors examine the concept of universal intelligence, which is aimed at applying commonly expressed ideas about intelligence to arbitrary systems and contexts, not just humans, as described in [1]. The theoretical foundations of AI are based on well-known theories, definitions, and tests of human intelligence developed by psychologists, with a focus on the essence of intelligence in the broadest possible terms. This approach is outlined in [1]. Additionally, the system presented in [2] is Turing-equivalent, meaning it can model the workings of a universal Turing machine, and offers insights into the nature of 'intelligence'. Regarding the evolution of definitions for AI, the authors of [1] claim that they provide a general survey of definitions and tests of machine intelligence. They note that there are numerous surveys of the Turing Test and its variants, but this section is the first general survey of definitions and tests of machine intelligence to their knowledge. Insufficient evidence exists to trace the historical evolution of AI definitions beyond the scope of these two publications. References:
[1] 0712.3329v1.pdf (2007)
[2] 0311031v1.pdf (2018)
